newsitem.title: UK: Australian sugar output may hit 6.0 m tns by 2001.
newsitem.headline: Australian sugar output may hit 6.0 m tns by 2001.

text.p: Australian sugar production could rise to as much as 6.0 million tonnes in the next five years, the general manager of the Australian Sugar Milling Council said on Wednesday.
"There are increasing constraints, such as distance....but these are individual not government decisions," said John Desmarchelier at a seminar hosted by the International sugar Organization (ISO).
"I would think that the industry would progress towards production of six million tonnes," he said.
Earlier, Desmarchelier said he expected Australian sugar output to rise to 5.30 million tonnes in the 1996 calendar year from 4.99 million in 1995.

Asked how the Australian sugar industry, concentrated in Queensland, would fare with the expected increase in production if world market prices fell, he said: "I'd think we're survive for a couple of years if the price fell to nine or eight cents a pound," referring to the New York No.11 futures contract.

But if the price stayed under 10 cents a pound for too long, "the industry would start to feel uncomfortable", he added. Nearby raw sugar prices are currently hovering around 10.60 cents a pound on the New York market.
